speech.summary: Parnell discussed a recent debate in the House of Commons and made historical allusions to Grattan and O'Connell
Parnell seconded a motion stating that the Land Act 1870 was insufficient
Parnell spoke at a meeting of the Irish Home Rule League, seconding a motion to admit new members
Parnell discussed Home Rule, political prisoners, and the 1870 Land Act
Parnell spoke against the Peace Preservation (Ireland) Bill
Parnell made a short statement during a Committee meeting opposing an amendment to the Peace Preservation (Ireland) Bill
Upon returning home from London, Parnell addressed a crowd
Parnell made a short intervention in the Committee debate on the Coercion Bill
Parnell denied the existence of 'Ribbonism' in Westmeath
Parnell asked a question relating to a constituency matter
Parnell asked a question relating to a constituency matter
Parnell asked a question relating to a constituency matter
Parnell seconded a motion at a Home Rule meeting
Parnell spoke about the treatment of Irish political prisoners
Parnell spoke against the Government's attempt to alter the order of business
Parnell spoke about the Irish education system
Parnell addressed a meeting in Hyde Park about the treatment of political prisoners
Parnell asked a question about a constituency matter
Parnell asked a question relating to the sentencing of John O'Brien
Parnell chaired a meeting of the Amnesty Association
Parnell spoke on the matter of the supply of vestments in Irish jails and workhousees
Parnell responded to the toast
Parnell addressed a Home Rule demonstration and spoke about Home Rule, political prisoners, and the 1798 rebellion
Parnell addressed his constituents, speaking about Home Rule and denominational education
Parnell spoke about Home Rule, religious education, and political prisoners
Parnell made a short speech encouraging his audience to show resolve
Parnell spoke about Home Rule and the activities of the Irish party at Westminster at a meeting of the Ancient Order of Foresters
Parnell participated in a heated debate during a meeting of the O'Connell Centenary Committee
Parnell spoke at a weekly meeting of the Home Rule League
Parnell spoke alongside Isaac Butt at a meeting of the Home Rule Confederation of Great Britain
Parnell spoke about the importance of Home Rule
Parnell spoke about Irish political prisoners
Parnell asked the First Lord of the Admiralty a question about the HMS Vanguard
Parnell gave notice of a forthcoming question
Parnell asked the Chief Secretary for Ireland a question
Parnell asked the Under Secretary of State for India a question relating to the dismissal of a soldier from the Bombay Native Army
Parnell asked the Secretary of State for War a question concerning the Militia
Parnell asked two questions concerning the case of Edward O'Meagher Condon
Parnell gave notice that he intended to move for leave to introduce a bill dealing with tenants' rights
According to several newspapers, Parnell gave notice that he intended to ask a question relating to crime in Ireland; however, the Irish Times insisted that this was a misattribution
Parnell attempted to make a speech but the House would not listen to him and he pushed for an adjournment to the debate
Parnell asked a question about a constitutency matter
Parnell presented a number of petitions to the House
Parnell asked two questions concerning the blending of Irish and Scotch whiskies
Parnell rebuked Lord Elcho for his statements on the Irish Land Bill
Parnell condemned the sale of food that was not fit for consumption to merchant ships
Parnell made a speech about the release of Irish political prisoners
Parnell made several short interventions relating to Parliamentary procedure and also condemned M.P.s who did not attend debates but turned up to vote anyway
Parnell made a speech asking the Galway electorate to vote for Captain O'Shea, explaining why he recommended O'Shea and the misunderstanding regarding Lynch's candidacy
Parnell made another a speech asking the Galway electorate to vote for Captain O'Shea, explaining why he recommended O'Shea and the misunderstanding regarding Lynch's candidacy
Parnell seconded a motion of thanks and referred to Lynch as a symbol of unity
Parnell made a speech on the first Home Rule bill
Parnell made a controversial speech on the second reading of the Home Rule bill, touching on the question of the Protestant minority
Parnell demanded time to debate the amendment to the Landlord and Tenant (Ireland) Act
Parnell spoke on the selection of a new Chief Secretary for Ireland
Parnell commented on discrepancies between the duties levied on whiskey and champagne
Parnell objected to an amendment to the Registration of Voters (Ireland) Bill
Parnell protested against an attempt to silence F. H. O'Donnell
Parnell made a long speech on the Relief of Distress (Ireland) Bill, arguing that land tenure was the principal cause of distress
Parnell demanded that more time be given for Irish members to consider the Relief of Distress (Ireland) Bill
Parnell moved the second reading of the Relief of Distress (Ireland) Bill
Parnell challenged the government's claim that the new land bill represented a final settlement to the issue
Parnell explained his reasons for voting to admit the atheist MP Charles Bradlaugh to Parliament
Parnell argued for the government giving a grant to the Irish Poor Law Boards
Parnell proposed an amendment to the Relief of Distress Act 1880
Parnell reacted strongly against the charge that Irishmen, specifically fishermen in this case, demonstrated a "deficiency in moral character"
Parnell accused the Liberal government of 'weakness and vacillation' over its approach to the Land Question
Parnell made several speeches including one in which he denied that he and his party were engaged in obstruction
Parnell made several interventions including asking the Chief Secretary about the presence of the police note-takers at political meetings in Ireland
Parnell made a lengthy speech about the behaviour of Irish landlords in which he also complained at how the newspapers portrayed an intervention he made several days earlier
Parnell made a speech dealing with aspects of parliamentary procedure
Parnell gave the infamous speech in which he reportedly claimed to want to break the 'last link' between Ireland and Great Britain
Parnell made his famous speech about how no one had the right to fix the boundary of the march of a nation
Parnell made a speech to the Irish electors of Liverpool announcing his candidature for the Exchange Division of the city
Parnell spoke in answer to the Queen's speech to Parliament
Parnell spoke to a large audience which included members of the Royal Irish Regiment to explain the importance of passing the Home Rule Bill
Parnell addressed an audience of nearly 10,000, discussing Home Rule and the Protestant minority
Parnell spoke to the Irish electors of Liverpool asking them to elect T. P. O'Connor
Parnell made a short speech upon his arrival in America, denouncing the Irish land system and appealing for help to relieve distress in Ireland
Parnell spoke in response to an address from Meath men who lived in America
Parnell made a long speech about the Irish land system
Parnell spoke about how the land movement would force the British government to make changes to the land system
Parnell made a non-political speech asking for aid to prevent famine in Ireland
Parnell spoke at length about the Irish land question, suggesting Prussia as an model for its settlement
Parnell made his stock appeal to US public opinion, criticizing the Irish land system

Parnell spoke about the Irish land system and noted that the British government only acted to solve Irish problems when they were forcibly thrust into the centre of English attention through violent acts. However, he emphasised that he did not support violence as a means of achieving his aims. On the other hand, he suggested that if the land question was not resolved then in future some might try to get justice through violent means.
Parnell spoke to a small audience, thanking them for his reception and explaining the severity of the famine in Ireland.
Parnell spoke about the land system in Ireland and remarked that the Irish were 'defenceless', as the right to bear arms was denied to them
Parnell discussed the fallacy that Ireland was overcrowded, comparing the country to The Netherlands and Belgium
Parnell delivered a lecture on the history of parliament in Ireland
Parnell spoke at a banquet held in his honour, discussing Ireland's right to nationhood and criticising how the British government had managed Irish affairs since the Union

Parnell spoke at the Wicklow Convention of the Irish party, speaking about the right of an Irish parliament to protect Irish industries and arguing that granting Home Rule would remove 'the greatest peril to the English Empire'
Parnell made an impromtu speech in which he attacked rack-renting and landlords' attempts to circumvent the Land Acts
Parnell proposed a toast to 'Ireland a nation', expressing confidence that Home Rule was imminent and warning people against emigration so that 'the Irish race' might be protected

Parnell made a brief speech recollecting the people of Charleville's activity during the land war and declaring that major reforms such as admission to the franchise would be nothing compared to the progress 'the Irish race' would make in the coming years
Parnell thanks the local Naltional League branch for its welcome and claimed that their local concerns were of great importance to Irish leaders
Parnell thanked the people of Ennis for their support over the years, declaring that their support for his chosen candidate in 1879 was a 'turning point' in his history and the history of Ireland
After the ceremonial turning of the first sod on the West Clare Railway, Parnell hoped that the coming of the railway would bring prosperity to the region

Parnell invoked the memory of the Land War, laying out the positive results that resulted from that movement, and rebuked the people for not financially supporting those who lost their homes from their involvement with the Land League
Parnell welcomed the president of the Land League of America to London, extolling his virtue as a leading Irish-American and urging supporters to be moderate in their efforts to secure Home Rule

Parnell spoke about the Irish party's record during the previous Parliament and looked forward to the election, arguing that the parliamentary party should have a say in the selection of candidates throughout the constituencies
Parnell chaired a meeting of the National League, setting out his ambition for the coming election and stressing that moderation would be vital to the early success of the Home Rule movement

Parnell denounced British rule in Ireland as a 'gigantic system of robbery and fraud' and declared that it would almost be better to deal with the Tories than the Liberals, as the Liberals were 'wolves in sheep's clothing'
Parnell spoke out against the nationalisation of land, arguing that this had never been the objective of the Land League and never should be in future
Parnell made a short speech from the window of the National League Rooms welcoming Thomas Sexton, M.P., back from the United States
Parnell addressed a large meeting held to celebrate a year of the land agitation and he called on the people to renew their efforts

Parnell spoke about the objectives of the land movement and predicted that it would not be long before the Irish people would realise the 'dreams of Grattan, of Emmett, of Fitzgerald, and of every patriotic Irishman' and bring an end to 'British misrule'
Parnell said that farmers would not do the cause any good by giving evidence before the Land Commission and encouraged the people to treat 'landgrabbers' like lepers
Parnell claimed that the only way to force the British government to act was to organise and declared had it not been for the land movement the Irish people would have been 'exterminated'
Parnell called for the present land system to be swept away and asked the audience to fight for their right to own the land they till
Parnell spoke about problems with the idea of fixity of tenure and demanded that the Irish people take control of the power to legislate for Ireland
Parnell made his famous speech in which he declared taht he would not have taken his coat off to help tenant farmers if he did not think it would have led to legislative independence
Parnell spoke about the land movement and its support in America, Australia, and France
Parnell made a speech about how best to amend the Land Act to suit Irish tenants, referenced the famine, and ended with a demand that Ireland be allowed to govern itself
Parnell spoke about the land question and asked his constituents to re-elect him when the time came

Parnell encouraged his audience to continue protesting within the bounds of the law and stated that the British government was determined to crush the Irish as they had 'the disunited Afghans' and 'after having conquered the naked Zulus' and rebuked it for having the 'temerity to come to Ireland and place us on a level with these savages'
Parnell spoke ending the landlord system, suggested that the only way to solve the matter to the satisfaction of the farmer and the labourer was a 'programme of free land'
Parnell encouraged people to continue the land agitation and told them to be wary of Gladstone, calling him the 'most unrivalled slanderer of the Irish nation that ever undertook the task'
Parnell praised his audience for their devotion to the Land League and urged them not to trust English legislation, such as the Land Act
